Most Flash memory sticks are not suitable to run a Windows OS on for long (years) periods of time (unless specifically designed for the purpose)

1. The memory used in most flash sticks is not specified to have high write-cycle usage.
2. The controllers used in them do not have wear-levelling, good error correction, automatic bad block detection and substitution and other advanced features
3. Unless USB 3.0, they are too slow.
4. They are not designed for high I/O for long periods of time - this can lead to overheating and a more rapid degradation of the components

For similar reasons, if you are going to build a reliable server, you would not use desktop hard disks, but would select server grade hard disks.

For your project, I would suggest a USB 3 caddy + SSD drive or SATA SSD.

Alternatively, make the OS boot flash drive read-only (or limit writes to it) - and have a USB 3 flash drive for the page file and data volume. That way you can replace either one easily if you get a fail as long as you take backups regularly.

Yes, (yes, yes, yes!).

But first let's try clearing the possible causes of the issues you reported.

What you report is really "queer" but it can be easily explained if you think how slow a USB stick controller normally is and how fast, by comparison, the correspondet USB bus is.

On good ol' USB 2.0 a USB hard disk "topped" at between 30 and 40 Mb/sec, whilst even fast USB sticks would be around HALF that speed.

It is possible that the same happens with USB 3.0 and what you report are simply timing problems.

Having a pagefile on a flash device (and having it managed by the system ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)) is "pure folly" as I see it, you can run Windows alright (if you have enough RAM) and at the most - since a few programs do require the existence of pagefile, but this should NOT apply to your case - make a very small pagefile, manually set to fixed size.

Back to the question.

The ONLY advantages of a USB stick are:

1. plug/unplug capabilities
2. hot-plug capabilities
3. portability/small size

And those of a USB hard disk only the first two:

1. plug/unplug capabilities
2. hot-plug capabilities

Since you DO NOT need hot-plug capabilities at all (since you have the actual OS on the device), and you don't need portability either, you are anyway going down a "wrong path".

A simple e-sata disk (which is a "normal" SATA bus) is much more "direct" than any USB one (and still is hot-pluggable, though it doesn't apply to your case).

For the record, DOM's (Disk on Module) devices:

[http://en.wikipedia..../Disk_on_module](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disk_on_module "External link")

have been used traditionally on such "embedded" systems.

DOM's use (at a dear price) "better" (if you prefer more "stable") memory chips than any USB stick you can normally find on the market.

Get a SATA DOM (examples here):

[http://www.memorydep...iskonmodule.asp](http://www.memorydepot.com/ssd_diskonmodule.asp "External link")

or a SSD and be done with it.

(but still a "plain" Windows 7 is one of the least suitable OS for your goal)

These modules are made for that, they suffer not from vibrations/shocks, have a wider operating temperature range when compared to hard disks, on the other side they are terribly expensive and offer very little capacity when compared to any hard disk.

If size (and power consumption) is not an issue, get a conventional hard disk, again SATA/e-sata will behave better than any USB solution.

Most Flash memory sticks are not suitable to run a Windows OS on for long (years) periods of time (unless specifically designed for the purpose)

1. The memory used in most flash sticks is not specified to have high write-cycle usage.
2. The controllers used in them do not have wear-levelling, good error correction, automatic bad block detection and substitution and other advanced features
3. Unless USB 3.0, they are too slow.
4. They are not designed for high I/O for long periods of time - this can lead to overheating and a more rapid degradation of the components

For similar reasons, if you are going to build a reliable server, you would not use desktop hard disks, but would select server grade hard disks.

For your project, I would suggest a USB 3 caddy + SSD drive or SATA SSD.

Alternatively, make the OS boot flash drive read-only (or limit writes to it) - and have a USB 3 flash drive for the page file and data volume. That way you can replace either one easily if you get a fail as long as you take backups regularly.

But first let's try clearing the possible causes of the issues you reported.

What you report is really "queer" but it can be easily explained if you think how slow a USB stick controller normally is and how fast, by comparison, the correspondet USB bus is.

On good ol' USB 2.0 a USB hard disk "topped" at between 30 and 40 Mb/sec, whilst even fast USB sticks would be around HALF that speed.

It is possible that the same happens with USB 3.0 and what you report are simply timing problems.

Having a pagefile on a flash device (and having it managed by the system ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)) is "pure folly" as I see it, you can run Windows alright (if you have enough RAM) and at the most - since a few programs do require the existence of pagefile, but this should NOT apply to your case - make a very small pagefile, manually set to fixed size.

Back to the question.

The ONLY advantages of a USB stick are:

1. plug/unplug capabilities
2. hot-plug capabilities
3. portability/small size

And those of a USB hard disk only the first two:

1. plug/unplug capabilities
2. hot-plug capabilities

Since you DO NOT need hot-plug capabilities at all (since you have the actual OS on the device), and you don't need portability either, you are anyway going down a "wrong path".

A simple e-sata disk (which is a "normal" SATA bus) is much more "direct" than any USB one (and still is hot-pluggable, though it doesn't apply to your case).

For the record, DOM's (Disk on Module) devices:

[http://en.wikipedia..../Disk_on_module](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disk_on_module "External link")

have been used traditionally on such "embedded" systems.

DOM's use (at a dear price) "better" (if you prefer more "stable") memory chips than any USB stick you can normally find on the market.

Get a SATA DOM (examples here):

No amount of RAM will do. ![:w00t:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)

The point is that Windows 7 thinks that ANYWAY a pagefile is needed (if the setting is "Let windows manage").

And anyway it sets it to some "dynamic" values, BUT as I see it, these values are normally completely "wrong" AND the idea of a "dynamic" pagefile is completely foolish.

On the other hand Windows NT based systems tend to manage RAM in a rather good way.

So, if you actually need/want a pagefile, set it manually to a suitable fixed size and be done with it.

In case you should need it, some history. ![:dubbio:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif)

A windows NT based system ***is*** memory hungry.

BUT there are ***limits*** to it's hunger.

In the good ol'times you had (if you were lucky) a 128 Mb system (more commonly a 64 Mb one) running NT 4.0, the solution to it was simple, elegant and smart:

* make a pagefile, typically sized 1.5 to 2.5 times the actual RAM

BUT also disk space was a very precious asset, so, the idea of making a pagefile "growing" or "dynamic" made some (though still little) sense.

So a typical NT 4.00 machine worked having 64 Mb of RAM and a pagefile at the most 2.5x that size, i.e. 160 Mb, the TOTAL amount of memory would have been 64+160=224 Mb.

If you take that same UNMODIFIED install/system, and you add to it a few sticks of ram, getting the total of RAM to 256 Mb and completely remove the pagefile, you are having MORE usable memory than you had before (and a lot faster system).

The NT tries to use available RAM as mich as possible and starts using the pagefile only in exceptional cases, i.e. when it really-really needs it.

If you replace the pagefile with more RAM, the NT will whirl away happily.

Please understand that if an app crashes and starts eating memory, it will typically do so until all memory is used, so what actually happens is that the RAM is earten, then the pagefile starts being eaten and grows, adding additionally disk activities, possibly becoming fragmented and thus contributing to fragment the filesystem, until it reaches the "maximum size", and then it crashes anyway.

So, if you have a "dynamic" pagefile is only a way to delay a little bit the crash, and since nowadays disk space is not anymore an issue, setting it as "fixed" makes much more sense.

Then it comes to the issue of size, the 1.5 to 2.5 multipliers made sense ONLY in the times where RAM quantities were minimal.

But the pagefile is also used for two other uses:

1. crash dumps
2. some apps, mainly graphics ones, like the mentioned photoshop, use it because at the time there were already huge graphic files (and little amount of RAM)

For the first, it is of no use, if you actually have a crash, you normally do not immediately analyze the pagefile "as is" to find traces of what happened, you rather set the whole system in trace/debug mode and try to replicate the crash.

For the second, the \*need\* for a pagefile is most often a remainder of the good ol' times, and it's size is irrelevant, you won't hit it anyway (and in the case you actually hit it, and do it often the solution is to increase the RAM, NOT to increase the pagefile size).

A rule of thumb (as a matter of fact much more accurate that the mentioned 1.5÷2.5 one for the pagefile size, that makes no sense on modern huge RAM systems) is to take the MS RAM requirements for a given OS knowing that they represent 1/2 of what is needed to have a merely decently running systems and 1/4 of what is needed to have a good running system (and not strictly \*needing\* a pagefile).

Of course actual kind of usage of the PC may and will make a difference, anything "graphics" will ask for more RAM than that and it would be smart to provide that RAM (as opposed to addign a pagefile or increasing it's size).

Applying the above rule of thumb a 4 Gb for 7 32 bit and 8 Gb for 7 64 bit would be enough.
